intro: Cousinia joharchii, commonly known as the Karakoram globemallow, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive seed capsules and often hairy foliage. The plant is characterized by its compact growth habit, with erect stems and clusters of small, yellowish flowers. Its leaves are typically narrow and covered in fine hairs, adapted to the harsh, high-altitude environments it inhabits. Cousinia joharchii is often found in rocky soils and is a resilient species capable of surviving in cold and arid conditions.
